rev.diff:
Line 32: Line 32:
==History==
==History==
[[File:Duck Amuck.jpg|left|thumb|200px|A scene from ''Duck Amuck''.]]
[[File:Duck Amuck.jpg|left|thumb|200px|A scene from ''Duck Amuck''.]]
â
[[File:Duck Amuck.gif|left|thumb|200px|Another scene from ''Duck Amuck''.]]
 
According to director [[Chuck Jones]], this film demonstrated for the first time that animation can create ''characters'' with a recognizable personality, independent of their appearance, [[Social environment|milieu]], or voice. Although in the end, the animator is revealed to be Daffy's rival [[Bugs Bunny]] (who famously declares "Ain't I a stinker?"), according to Jones the ending is just for comedic value: Jones (the director) is speaking to the audience directly, asking "Who is Daffy Duck anyway? Would you recognize him if I did ''this'' to him? What if he didn't live in the woods? Didn't live anywhere? What if he had no voice? No face? What if he wasn't even a duck anymore?" In all cases, it is obvious that Daffy is still Daffy; not all cartoon characters can claim such distinctive personality.

Although in the end, the animator is revealed to be Daffy's rival [[Bugs Bunny]] (who famously declares "Ain't I a stinker?"), according to Jones the ending is just for comedic value: Jones (the director) is speaking to the audience directly, asking "Who is Daffy Duck anyway? Would you recognize him if I did ''this'' to him? What if he didn't live in the woods? Didn't live anywhere? What if he had no voice? No face? What if he wasn't even a duck anymore?" In all cases, it is obvious that Daffy is still Daffy; not all cartoon characters can claim such distinctive personality.
